newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: Journalists' jailing hits Zambia independent press.
newsitem.headline: Journalists' jailing hits Zambia independent press.

text.p: Zambia's leading independent daily, The Post, faces further court action in Lusaka this week amid mounting concern that the government of President Frederick Chiluba is pursuing a drive to muzzle the press.
Fred Mmembe, a Post editor, was due to appear in magistrate's court on Thursday on libel charges for publishing an article last year in which he claimed Chiluba had fathered a love child.
Mmembe, one of three journalists awaiting trial on charges brought by the Chiluba government, could face three years' imprisonment if convicted.
Earlier this month another Post editor, Masausto Phiri, became the first Zambian journalist to be jailed on contempt of court charges.
He was imprisoned for publishing reports that the Supreme Court judges took government bribes to reject an opposition challenge of the results of controversial general elections held last year.
Phiri's three-month jail sentence provoked a flurry of protests from local and international media watchdog groups, who say it was too harsh for the offence committed.

Last Sunday, the editor of the independent Chronicle, Lweendo Hamusankwa, was arrested for publishing an allegedly false report on a break-in at a military base. The reporter who wrote the article, Boyd Phiri, who is not related to the Post editor, was detained the following day.
Both are still being held and are to be charged with criminal libel and for publishing "false news" with intent to cause fear and alarm to the public.
The Press Association of Zambia has called on journalists "not to be intimidated...but to continue in their efforts to uphold the tenets of freedom of the press".
Media observers say Masausto Phiri's imprisonment is just one symptom of a concerted government clampdown on the media.
By December last year, The Post faced at least 19 criminal and civil lawsuits, most filed by government officials. But the goverment denies any campaign against the press.
Commenting on the Post editor, who admitted that his reports were not based on established fact, the state-run Times of Zambia said:

"Because of a few bad eggs, the whole media can now be sensed most perceptibly as out-and-out fabricators. (Zambians) should condemn anyone within the media fraternity who tried to make it look as if Phiri was a victim of press harassment, for he was not."

Last November, the government suspended six journalists at the state-run broadcaster whom it believed were sympathetic to the opposition or worked with watchdog groups which questioned the fairness of November's elections.

Chiluba won a landslide in the ballot, boycotted by opposition groups who said he had stacked the deck against them. In January, Chiluba announced that he would establish a media council to curb malpractice and two weeks later the ministry of information announced that it would "expose" journalists who sent "negative" reports on Zambia.
The government has also passed legislation compelling journalists to disclose their sources before a tribunal appointed by the chief justice.
Some analysts say the state, which owns the only national radio and television network and the two more established dailies, is determined to tame the independent media.
The independent media comprises one daily and four weeklies with a total circulation of around 20,000 copies, plus two community radio stations.
